name: Neo-Y evolution with male recombination
description: Drosophila albomicans has a pair of young neo-sex chromosomes. Surprisingly, the males of this species used to recombine. We explore the effects recombination has had on the neo-Y chromsome.

name: Assembling the massive neo-Y of D. miranda
description: Drosophila miranda has a neo-Y chromosome that is ~1 million years old. Because it is heavily degenerate with pseudogenes and repetitive elements, we used multiple state-of-the-art genome assembly technologies to piece it together. This includes Pac-Bio, BAC clone, and BioNano sequencing and scaffolding with chromosome contact data (Hi-C). The resulting neo-Y chromosome is in two contigs, and is three times the size of the ancestral autosome from which it derived.\nMahajan, S., Wei, K. H.-C., Nalley, M. J., Gibilisco, L. & Bachtrog, D. De novo assembly of a young Drosophila Y chromosome using single-molecule sequencing and chromatin conformation capture. PLoS Biol. 16, e2006348 (2018).

name: Evolution of simple satellites in Drosophila
description: We profiled the simple satellite landscape across 9 Drosophila species. We found a surprising large amount of diversity driven predominantly by the gains of lineage-specific satellites. Interestingly, newly emerged satellites are also closely related in sequence to existing satellites, suggesting that new satellites are frequently birthed from pre-exising ones.\nWei, K. H.-C. et al. Variable Rates of Simple Satellite Gains across the Drosophila Phylogeny. Mol. Biol. Evol. 35, 925–941 (2018).

name: Detecting meiotic drive with pooled sequencing
description: We developed a novel approach that integrates classical genetics with genomics to identify non-Mendelian transmission frequency. Rather than genotyping single individuals, we inferred the transmission rate from pooled sequenceing of large number of individuals. Using this approach we identified a weak centromeric driver.\nWei, K. H.-C. et al. A Pooled Sequencing Approach Identifies a Candidate Meiotic Driver in Drosophila. Genetics 206, 451–465 (2017).

name: Mini-review: The sex chromosome evolution cycle
description: Based on the papers from Vicoso & Bachtrog 2014 and 2012, where they inferred the sex chromosome karyotypes across dipterans.\nWei, K. H.-C. & Barbash, D. A. Never settling down: frequent changes in sex chromosomes. PLoS Biol. 13, e1002077 (2015).

name: Natural variation in simple satellites of D. melanogaster
description: Using a new pipeline I developed (k-seek), we characterized the satellite composition across 87 strains of D. melanogaster. We found population differentiation patterns that are surprisingly different from the pattern based on SNP data. We also found that the abundance of many satellites are correlated among strains, suggesting that some satellites are coevolving.\nWei, K. H.-C., Grenier, J. K., Barbash, D. A. & Clark, A. G. Correlated variation and population differentiation in satellite DNA abundance among lines of Drosophila melanogaster. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 111, 18793–18798 (2014).
